repnme.cdata!: Gambia - Water Supply and Electricity Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Water and Electricity Project of The
            Gambia. The project's main objectives were to: (a) to
            provide an essential service to the people Of Greater Banjul
            Area (GBA) by increasing water supplies in areas of
            suppressed demand and expanding the public water supply
            system; (b) to provide improved water supply service in
            seven provincial urban centers by rehabilitation and limited
            expansion of the existing systems; (c) to reduce line losses
            through the reinforcement and rehabilitation of the
            electricity distribution system in Greater Banjul; and (d)
            to assist Gambia Utilities Corporation (GUC) in achieving
            financial viability through improved operational efficiency
            and financial management by implementing adequate tariff
            increases for water and electricity, designing and
            implementing a system of human resources management which
            included training, and providing working capital support to
            GUC for the purchase of about a nine month supply of diesel
            fuel. Bank performance is rated deficient. Borrower
            performance is rated deficient. The projects' outcome
            is rated highly unsatisfactory. The following reflect the
            lessons learned: (1) the Bank should be more decisive in
            enforcing compliance with covenants. Constant use of threat
            without follow through action does not produce the desired
            results. The Bank should not hesitate to suspend a project
            for non compliance with covenants and it should be willing
            to cancel a project when it deems that any altemative will
            not resolve the problem; (2) measures to improve
            institutional and financial performance have to be initiated
            up-front and have a more comprehensive approach, i.e.
            include monitoring indicators for example, than what was
            included in the project; (3) projects should be presented to
            the Board only when preparation is sufficiently advanced
            with detailed engineering for the first phase completed, and
            not to meet lending targets; (4) a genuine and continuous
            commitment from Government to a carefully analyzed and
            planned program is a prerequisite for International
            Development Association (IDA) support and IDA should not
            hesitate to suspend or cancel a credit if the Government is
            not sufficiently committed to the objectives of the project;
            (5) the maximum time allowed for credit effectiveness should
            not exceed 12 months; (6) project financing should be
            secured and finalized before appraisal and contracts awarded
            in good time to avoid delays; (7) in management leasing
            contracts the necessity of an adequate institutional
            framework, a carefully designed incentive environment, an
            effective regulatory capacity plus the participation of not
            only the Government and the utility but also its staff and
            customers are key.

Gambia - Water And Electricity
            Project : Credit 1724 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Water Supply and Electricity Project
            will (a) expand the water supply facilities in the Greater
            Banjul area; (b) rehabilitate and expand public water
            supplies in seven provincial urban areas; and (c) improve
            the electricity supply distribution system in Greater
            Banjul.  It will also (d) assist the Gambia Utilities
            Corporation to become a financially viable public utility
            and to improve service to its existing and new customers.
            As a result, this project will provide and/or improve,
            directly or indirectly, the water supply to 295,000 people
            in Greater Banjul and to 25,000 people in seven provincial
            urban areas as well as improve the reliability of
            electricity supplies for 47,000 people in Banjul.
